description: Used in English since the 16th century. Via French moustache from Italian mostaccio, from early Medieval Latin mustācium, from Byzantine Greek μουστάκιον (moustákion), diminutive of (Doric) Ancient Greek μύσταξ (mústax, “upper lip”), from Proto-Indo-European *mendʰ- (“to chew”). Replaced native English kemp (“moustache”), from Old English cenep.

entries.meaning: A growth of facial hair between the nose and the upper lip.
examples: For more quotations using this term, see Citations:moustache.
